A common use case for me is to save attached files from various senders to certain file system locations. For example, a photo editor might receive attached JPEG files from numerous photographers, and save these attachments in folders identifying the source.

/home/ed/photographers/arthur/
/home/ed/photographers/ford/
/home/ed/photographers/zaphod/

It would be convenient if Thunderbird could remember the last location an attachment was saved based on sender address, so that, continuing the above example, the next time the editor tries to save an attachment from an email from Zophod, Thunderbird will offer to save it in ~/photographers/zaphod/.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Receive an email from Ford with an attachment.
2. Save the attached file in ~/photographers/ford/.
3. Receive an email from Arthur with an attachment.
4. Save the attached file in ~/photographers/arthur/.
5. Receive another email from Ford with another attachment.
6. Right-click the attachment icon and select "Save as...".

Actual Results:  
A file-system dialog allows me to browse to the location that I want to save the file, but crucially, the default location is ~/photographers/arthur/. If I want to save the file in ~/photographers/ford/, I need to do extra work.

Expected Results:  
Having previously saved an attachment from Ford in ~/photographers/ford/, I would prefer for Thunderbird to ignore the fact that I most recently saved an attachment in ~/photographers/arthur/ and offer to save the latest attachment to an email from Ford in the same place that I last saved an attachment from Ford: ~/photographers/ford/.
